characters: FOR THE WHEEL'S STILL IN SPIN
FOR THE TIMES THEY ARE A-CHANGIN'
FOR THE LOSER NOW WILL BE LATER TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get our bearings in a moment but right now we’re in middle of a conversation taking place on a stage between STEVE JOBS, JOANNA HOFFMAN and ANDY HERTZFELD--all late- 20's/early 30's.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: So what’s the upshot?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It’s not gonna say “Hello.”

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It absolutely is gonna say “Hello.”

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It’s nobody’s fault, (it’s a system error).

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) You built the voice demo.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Look--  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Keep your voices down.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: The voice demo is flaky. I’ve been telling you that for--this thing is overbuilt.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: 1984 Flint Auditorium DeAnza Community College

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It worked last night, it worked the night before that, it worked three hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It’s not working now so just skip (over the)--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Shh.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Skip over--everything else is working. Skip over the voice demo.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We need it to say “Hello.”

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You're not hearing me, it’s (not gonna) --

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) Fix it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Fix it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 3.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (are you serious?) In 40 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Fix it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Who’s the person who can?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I’m the person who can and I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: How bad are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It’s pretty bad.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It means (the demo is more than likely gonna crash).

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (over) You have to keep your voices down, Joel Pforzheimer is sitting out in the house.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don’t care if--who’s Joel Pforzheimer?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: GQ. He’s been shadowing you for a week, did you notice?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Just look like everything’s fine, he’s sitting out in the house. We reveal the 2,600 seat house which in 40 minutes will b filled to capacity. We’re at the launch of the Mac.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 4.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There are hundreds of seats with “Reserved For” signs on for the various Apple teams--"Macintosh”, “Apple II”, “Li as well as hundreds of members of the press--"New York Times”, “Newsweek”, “Wall Street Journal”, “Financial Tim of London”, “Le Monde”, etc. JOEL PFORZHEIMER is out ther credentials around his neck, and he gives a small wave to Steve and so are 50 or 60 ENGINEERS, DESIGNERS and MARKET who are observing the rehearsal from various vantage poin Way in the back is CHRISANN BRENNAN, 31, and her daughter LISA BRENNAN, 5, who’s tucked in a big coat. STEVE, JOANNA and ANDY are standing in front of a giant screen showing a slide of the Mac. JOANNA is a beautiful, brilliant, dryly-funny Polish immigrant who speaks with a slight trace of an accent. ANDY is a sweet, cherubic youn guy--if you put a bow and arrow in his hands he’d look li Cupid. Nobody has slept for days.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to ANDY) Alright, what are your guys saying?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Some kind of race condition but we haven’t been able to track it down yet.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Is the synthesizer sampling fast enough?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: No, so the rates are off and it keeps crashing.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (to STEVE) It’s 20 seconds out of a two-hour launch, why not just cut it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We can’t cut it.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Yeah, you just (cut it).

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) Two days ago we ran a Super Bowl ad that could’ve won the Oscar for Best Short Film. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 5.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are more people who can tell you about the ad than can tell you who won the game.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I understand, but the ad said the Mac was gonna save the world, it didn't say it was gonna say hello. ANDREA CUNNINGHAM, a 26-year-old publicist for Apple, cal from the back--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: We’re gonna open the house in five.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (calling back to ANDREA) Don’t open the house. (to the house) We're taking a quick break.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Part of the problem is--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: --what?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: We can recompile but if it’s a hardware problem we can’t get into the back.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (to STEVE) You want to tell her or should I?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to ANDY) Don't start with me, man.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Why can’t he get into the machine?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (to JOANNA) You need special tools.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: What kind of special tools, just take a screwdriver.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: He didn’t want users to be able to open it, you need special tools.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (to STEVE) Is this for real?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: There are a hundred engineers walking around here, none of them have the tools?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: In fairness, not many of them were issued the tools.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What about you? ANDY shrugs--

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I left them at the office, it was 3 A.M and--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus Christ--cut “hello.”

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: What’s the first rule of a launch?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s not gonna crash.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It just did.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (calling out to the house) Andy!

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The other Andy, you’re right there, why would I (be calling out into--)  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 7.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: He needs to talk to you. ANDREA CUNNINGHAM, the 26-year-old publicist, calls back-

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to ANDREA) The exit signs have to be off or we're not gonna get a full blackout.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: We've spoken to the building manager and the fire marshal.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: There’s absolutely no way they’re letting us turn the exit signs off.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I‘1ll pay whatever the fine is.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: The fine is they’re gonna come in and tell everyone to leave.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You explained to the fire marshal that we’re in here changing the world?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: I did, but unless we can also change the properties of fire he doesn’t care.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Steve-—

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: If a fire causes a stampede to the unmarked exits it will have been well worth it for those who survive. For those who don’t, less so but still pretty good.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 8.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Listen--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (still to ANDREA) I need it to go to black, real black, get rid of the exit signs and don’t let me know how you did it. (to ANDY) Fix the voice demo. STEVE leaves the stage, followed by JOANNA and heads--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You need special tools to open the Mac?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You knew it was a closed system.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I didn’t know literally, Jesus. JOANNA opens a door marked “STEVE JOBS” and gives STEVE a push into-- INT. STEVE’S DRESSING ROOM - CONTINUOUS The room’s been set aside as a place for Steve to chill, alone and prepare during rehearsals and before the big presentation. There’s a Mac (the original Mac) on a small table. There’s also a large, unopened carton that was recently delivered.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: And if you keep alienating people for no reason there’s gonna be no one left for it to say hello to.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s not for no reason. We blow this and IBM will own the next 50 years like a Batman villain. Remember the phone company? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s what Bell was called, the phone company. IBM will be the computer company and in 10 years they'll be the information company and that’s very bad for the human race so we don’t have time to be polite or realistic ‘cause if we are, this company’s next product launch will be held in front of 26 people and a stringer from the Alameda County Shopper's Guide.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: We--listen--we haven’t advertised the voice software. We could pull it out of the demo and no one would be disappointed. Do you want to try being reasonable just, you know, to see what it feels like?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Okay, pull the voice demo.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And then cancel the launch.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I see, you just (tricked me a little).

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) You can tell me how unimportant it is but if the computer doesn’t say hello then neither will John Sculley who, I promise you, agrees with me.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Sculley’s not gonna cancel the launch ‘cause he’s not insane.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: He’s also not a hack and when it comes to the Macintosh he’s gonna do what I ask him to do. What is in this box?  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 10.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Nothing you need to worry about, don’t even open it. STEVE opens the flaps on the box and pulls out an issue o Time magazine. “Machine of the Year” is on the cover with picture of a computer. It’s a carton full of copies of Ti

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) What the fuck is--why is there a carton of--who did this?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Somebody thought--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: --doesn’t matter--thought it would be a good idea to have copies of that Time cover available at everyone’s seat. It was nipped in the bud and all the copies are being taken out of the building-- they’re probably already out of the building so...problem solved.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: This isn’t a Macintosh.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Somebody thought it would be a good idea to, like, enthusiastically hand over copies of Time with a not- a-Macintosh on the cover at the launch of the Macintosh? What are they handing out at Hewlett- Packard, a bushel of apples with my face on them?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I’m sure the thinking was--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah?  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: --that since the computer is Man of the Year that that’s good for our business but like I said I’m having them removed from the building.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What I'd like you to do with them is to take them, all 2600 copies, and stack them on Kottke’s desk and tell him Steve says, “Happy New Year to you.”

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I gave Michael Moritz full access, the whole campus. Bandley, Apple II, Lisa, I gave him Sculley, Markkula, I gave him Woz, I gave him everybody. Betrayal, thy name is Michael Moritz and Bozo, thy name is Daniel Kottke. What should I call the person who thought it would be a good idea to hand these out?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I’m not telling you who it was, it was done without malice, it’s been taken care of, you have a half-hour and we have things to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Like a million in the first 90 days--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Joanna-—

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Twenty thousand a month after that.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Look--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I’m begging you-- 11.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Those are the forecasts.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: --because this is my field. I am begging you to manage expectations out there.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m fanning (expectations).

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (over) We’re not gonna sell a million in the first 90 days.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Everyone, everyone, everyone. Everyone is waiting for the Mac.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Maybe, but what happens when they find out that for twenty-four ninety-five there’s nothing you can do with it? STEVE stares at her...

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) We were competitive at 1500 but once you replaced the Motorola 6809 with the 68000--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: --which is what supports menus, windows, point and click, high res graphics--—

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Yeah, ‘cause everyone needs rectangles with rounded corners.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Coach lands on the runway at the exact same time as first class.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (beat) I don’t have the first fucking idea what that means but this is how it got to $2500. 12.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Okay--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Which is the price point on the PC which can do a lot more.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Who’s gonna want a PC once--what idiot is gonna want--if I need to tell you there’s a spot on your shirt I point to the spot, I don’t say there’s a spot 14 centimeters down from the collar and 3 centimeters to the right of the second button while I try to remember what the command is for club soda, that’s not how a person’s mind works.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: If the goal was ease of use, maybe you should've given it some memory.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You can complain about memory or you can complain about price but you can’t do both at the same time. Memory is what costs money. And I’m glad you're telling me your feelings about the Mac now because we have a half-hour left, we can redesign it.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I’m just asking you to (manage expectations).

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) Look at their faces when they see what it is. They won’t know what they’re looking at or why they like it but they’1l know they want it.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Not instantly. When people heard “Rite of Spring” they tore the chairs out of the theater, they didn't buy the record. 13.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: “Rite of Spring" happens to be the most revolutionary and provocative symphony of the last century.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Yes, exactly, but Igor Stravinsky didn’t say he was gonna sell 20,000 units a month.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It was 1913, there weren’t--I don’t know why we’re talking about Stravinsky when-- (holding up Time) --I've been properly sodomized by Dan Kottke in Time magazine.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Look, obviously--let me say this-- obviously Daniel didn’t think he was doing anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: By talking to Moritz about it?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You said--when you told me the story, you said, “Dan, did Michael Moritz ask you if I had a daughter named Lisa?” and Dan said, “Yeah” and you said, “What did you tell him?” and Dan said, “Yes.” My point was that he answered you simply and honestly because he didn’t think he’d done anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) Except, Joanna, except--I don't have a daughter named Lisa! (beat--picking up the magazine) And this story is now about how I’m denying paternity and took a blood test! (MORE )
STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that’s why there’s a picture of a--I don’t know what the fuck that is--that’'s why there’s a picture of a PC on the cover instead of a picture of me and the Mac. (beat) I don’t know what to tell you. I was supposed to be Time magazine's Man of the Year and then Dan Kottke was born.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (beat) Well...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: She's waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Chrisann.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Brennan?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: They're out in the hall. They've been sitting in the back of the auditorium since seven this morning, she wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: How did she get in?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Who was gonna stop her?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m not having a session with her right now.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: We issued 335 press credentials for the launch, Steve, you piss off Chrisann and she’s gonna stand in the lobby and give 335 interviews and you, pal, will be longing for the halcyon days of Dan Kottke. 15.  STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) Lemme get this over with. But don’t leave, you’re gonna stay here.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No, there’s less chance of a scene if you stay here, she’1ll be cool.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I find this all excruciatingly personal and I’m not staying.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be in a room alone with Chrisann. Come on, this is me and you.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Fine. STEVE goes to the door, opens it and steps out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where CHRISANN BRENNAN and LISA are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: This is a surprise, why don’t you come on in.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: Thank you. CHRISANN takes LISA’s hand to lead her--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to LISA) You coming too?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m not going to leave her in the hallway. into-- 16.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Okay. It’s a safe hallway, but...anyway-- They walk back into-- INT. STEVE’S DRESSING ROOM - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: --you remember Joanna Hoffman, she’s the head of marketing for the Mac.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: Good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Nice to see you. Hello, Lisa. We’ve met before and you told me you liked the way I talked and that was my favorite thing anyone’s ever said to me.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: You're from Poland.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Yes I am. Do you know where that is?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (pointing to the top of an imaginary globe) The top of the Earth.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I think you’re thinking of the North Pole.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well we’re a little pressed for time, so--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (heading for the door) I’ll leave you guys alone.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Why?...do you want to leave when (you just said)-- 17.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (over) I’m going to check in with Hertzfeld. (to LISA) We're trying to get a computer to say hello but right now it’s being very shy. Would you come help me? (to CHRISANN) Is it okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to JOANNA) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (to JOANNA) My dad named a computer after me.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I'm not your-- STEVE stops himself and sees the looks coming from both CHRISANN and JOANNA.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) That, actually--do you know what a coincidence is, Lisa? Like if you met someone, if you made a new friend and her name was Lisa too, that would be a coincidence. Lisa stands for “Local Integrated System Architecture”. L-I-S-A. It’s a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (pause) You about done?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (to LISA) Come. Let’s make that computer say hi. LISA’s still absorbing the “Lisa” information...  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: So it was the other way around--I was named after the computer?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Nothing was named after anybody, it’s a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Come on, hon. JOANNA and LISA exit.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you?!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you?! Why are you telling her these things? Why are you still telling her I’m her father?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: A judge told her you’re her father--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No he didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: --and where the hell do you get off telling Time magazine that I've slept with 28% of the men in America.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That’s not remote--

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: Where do you get off?!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That‘s not remotely what I said.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: (picking up the magazine) It’s right here.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: First of all, can I tell you something about Time magazine? (MORE )
STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I believe it’s a training facility for paid assassins.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: “Jobs insists”--I’m quoting--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I didn’t invent math.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: "'28% of the male population of the United States could be the father.'’”

dialogues.speaker: STEVE

dialogues.text: Here’s what I’m going to do. I’m going to announce the names of everyone who designed the launch demo--I’m gonna introduce everyone and ask them to stand up. The bag was designed by Susan Kare, the Macintosh font that’s scrolling across the screen was designed by Steve Capps, the starry night and the skywriting was Bruce Horn, MacPaint, MacWrite, Alice, down to the calculator and then I’m going to say the voice demo that didn’t work was designed by Andy Hertzfeld. ANDY laughs a little for a moment but STEVE stares at him ANDY realizes he’s serious. The others are looking down a trying to make themselves look busy but there’s no saving Andy here.

dialogues.text: Steve-—

(beat) Do it, Andy. ANDY nods to his team that they should come with him and back to work. dialogues.speaker: STEVE

STEVE looks at ANDY and mimes rolling the cartridge of a revolver and sticking it to his own head along with sound effects. dialogues.text: The members of the board, individually, believe that you're deranged, Chris. They were worried that you were going to sue me before the IPO and endanger the stock price. So I took a blood test, which I obviously wouldn’t have done if I didn’t think it would prove conclusively and for all time that I am not-- (he mouths--“her father”.) --and frankly I think telling her otherwise is child abuse.

dialogues.text: Now I gave you everything you wanted on the Apple II. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 40.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) We can’t possibly still be talking about the slots, man, it’s been seven years and-- woz I have a point. The eight slots on (the Apple II are what)--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) You're still doing it, you’re talking about the slots, there’s something wrong (with you). woz (over) The slots--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: This argument started in the garage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: woz Why would you only want two slots?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A printer and a modem. woz With eight slots you can--this is a huge deal that we were able to put in eight slots.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I appreciate the engineering but it’s not what we’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: woz And thank God I won that argument ‘cause-—

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Woz-- woz --the open system is what people love about the machine and it’s why it sold and still sells.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: An open system, we're not doing an open system. woz Of course we are. That’s what people want and the breakthrough on the Apple II is--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: People don’t know what they want until you show it to them. Edison didn’t do market research on the light bulb versus the candle. woz I think it went without saying that people would rather flip a switch than, you know, burn whale oil. Let me explain this world to you. Serious users--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Which world are you explaining? woz My world.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You live on the Planet Wozniak.  15 16 17 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 woz Serious users want to customize and modify, they want to jack it up, 42. 15 they want hardware engineers like me to expand its capabilities, okay? Keyboards for music, better sound boards, better display boards--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: woz And it’s why there are 3000 people here today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: woz --improved memory cards, they want ports!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They don’t get a vote. When Dylan wrote “Shelter From the Storm” he didn’t ask people to contribute to the lyrics. Plays don’t stop so the playwright can ask the audience what scene they’d like to see next. A painter-- woz Hobbyists--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We are on the verge of a tectonic-- hobbyists?!--a printer and a modem, two slots. 17

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: woz The slots are what allowed the Apple II to run, for just one example, VisiCalc, which my guess single-handedly sold between two and three-hundred thousand machines.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The Apple II team has my affection but I’m not loving up a seven year old product at the Mac launch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: woz Computers aren’t paintings.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Fuck you. I’m gonna say fuck you every time you say that until you either die or stop. Try it. woz Steve-—

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Say it. woz Computers aren’t (paintings).

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) Fuck you. Yes they are and what I want is a closed system. End to end control. Completely incompatible with anything. woz Computers aren’t supposed to have human flaws. Why would we want to incept this one with yours? The two friends look at each other silently...  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 44.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) This shouldn’t ruin our friendship. woz Nothing’s gonna ruin our friendship but if something did it wouldn’t be the number of slots on a machine, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some stragglers are making their way into the building an one of them spots the two Steves--

dialogues.speaker: STRAGGLER
dialogues.text: (shouting) Hey! Steve and Steve! They give a wave--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The Apple II is yours, I give you full credit. woz Thank you. But they need credit on this occasion and it’1ll take 30 seconds, two minutes tops-- They head back through the doors and into--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Today is about the Macintosh and the Mac is mine. woz I give you that.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thank you. woz I give you that. Just publicly acknowledge the Apple II team because it’s the right thing to do. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.text: WOZ heads Shooting Script 03/19/15 45.

dialogues.speaker: WOZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Mac is Jeff Raskin’s. STEVE looks at WOZ... WOZ takes They both

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) Say it for me. woz A computer’s not a (painting).

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) Fuck you. Woz (laughing a little) Alright. off as ANDREA CUNNINGHAM comes up to STEVE--

dialogues.text: (whispering) Hey! Joel Pforzheimer’s on the other side of that door. keep their voices down.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: (over) GQ. Steve, he’s asking for some clarification on Xerox PARC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 46.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: He’s asking about PARC?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: You need to go in there. I want him to hear it from you (and not someone else.)

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) How does he know about (PARC)?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: (over) I don’t know but he does. Is there something I need to know? STEVE shakes his head “no,” opens the door to a VIP room walks into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where the dozen or so people give STEVE a round of applause.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thanks guys. We’re gonna start, why don’t you go take your seats. Joel, stick around a second? The VIP’s file out, shaking STEVE’s hand or patting his shoulder or giving him a hug--"Good luck,” “Knock ‘em dea “Here we go,” etc. As soon as the room is empty--

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: I've been trying to get an answer on--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: PARC stands for Palo Alto Research Center--Xerox PARC. In the ‘70s they came up with something called “Gooey”--G-U-I--Graphical User Interface. Instead of typing commands they used the metaphor of a desktop and roughly the same idea as a McDonald’s cash register. You press a button with a picture of a cheeseburger.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 47.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: And you were shown the technology.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: And used it in the Macintosh.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You can draw a line from Xerox PARC to the Mac.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: What would you say--Steve, I’m not saying this but what would you say to someone who said you stole the Macintosh from Xerox?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Do you know who invented the piano?

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Do you know who wrote “Moonlight Sonata”?

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Beethoven.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That’s what I’d say. I'll see you after. STEVE heads out of the room and back into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where ANDY HERTZFELD and JOANNA are waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I need more time.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You can’t have it. They begin walking toward the door that leads to the stag

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Twenty minutes.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 48.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: We can start late.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hear me, we're a computer company, we can’t start late.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Then I have another idea. They walk through a door and are--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're behind the giant screen on which the whole presentation will be projected. Several Macs and their operators are at tables. We can hear the audience’s energ And we can see an ENGINEER with a small crowbar trying to find a spot to open the back of another Mac while a coupl other ENGINEERS stand around it with screwdrivers.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It’s deceptive and borderline unethical.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It‘’1l run on the Five-Twelve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You tested it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Wait, you’re gonna demo a 128 computer on a 512?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Nobody’s gonna know.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 49.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (to ANDY) And you think that’s borderline unethical?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Name my other choices please.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Please--you have to tell me why it’s so important for it to say hello.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hollywood. They made computers scary things. (pointing to a Mac) You see how this reminds you of a friendly face? That the disk slot is a goofy grin? It’s warm and it’s playful and inviting and it needs to say hello. It needs to say hello because it can. We hear a few dozen members of the audience--seated up in balcony--start to stamp their feet and clap their hands i rhythm, rock concert style. The few dozen turn into a few hundred. STEVE, JOANNA and ANDY silently take it in...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're not committing fraud. The 512 is gonna ship in under a year. Will you absolve me of your Eastern European disapproval?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (pause--resigned) The computer in 2001 said hello all the time and it still scared the shit out of--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Absolve me.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Just for this. And just for now. The house lights go out and we hear the audience break in THUNDEROUS APPLAUSE.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 50.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We hear a WOMAN’s voice over the PA system and see her speaking into a mic backstage--

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (VO)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome founding board member, Mike Markkula. We see the silhouette of MARKKULA walking to the podium a we'll be able to hear his opening remarks without paying attention to them.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Alright. Okay. Go make a dent in the universe, Steven.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: See you in a couple of hours. JOANNA heads off and disappears as MARKKULA’s opening rem continue. STEVE waits...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to ANDY) The last three run-throughs we’ve introduced the Mac exactly 41 minutes into the--

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The clock on the Mac needs to read 9:41.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: The clock’s gonna read whatever the time is, it’s a clock. STEVE takes a moment, nods, and turns to go head to where he’s supposed to wait backstage. He sees a welcoming sight--the first one of the day. It’s JOHN SCULLEY. SCULLEY’s a handsome and easygoing man abou years older than Steve. He’s got a bottle of wine and two glasses. STEVE smiles and walks over to him as the openin remarks continue in the background. STEVE hugs SCULLEY and they speak quietly--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thank merciful God, the cavalry’s shown up.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 51.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I hear you’ve been worse than usual this morning and I didn’t think that was possible. So I’ve been dispatched to be the Steve Whisperer. This is a ‘55 Margaux.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s nine in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: This is a ‘55 Margaux. SCULLEY starts pouring two glasses-- SCULLEY (CONT’D) Is it my imagination or have you started to dress like me?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It was a bad idea to have Markkula open with quarterly reports. Instead of having Markkula open we could have just dropped water on the audience. SCULLEY laughs a little--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, just big 10,000 gallon tanks of cold water dropped from the ceiling, save Mike some money on index cards.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Just relax.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (pause) I don’t know, no one’s ever asked that question. STEVE laughs a little. SCULLEY (CONT’D) There you go.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 52.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You’re the only person who sees the world the same way I do.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: No one sees the world the same way you do.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m like Julius Caesar, John, I'm surrounded by enemies.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: You're not.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The board--

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: The board's behind you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Only because you see to it they are.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: I think it’s a good board but if you want me to push ‘em out one by one we can talk about that.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I want you to push ‘em out all at once. Through a window if it’s the nearest exit. The looks on their faces when we showed ‘em the spot?

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: I couldn't see their faces ‘cause they were banging their heads on the table.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Some of them were frozen like they’d just seen “Springtime for Hitler."

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: My highlight was the silence that was broken by, “It’s supposed to be a play on the Orwell book, right?” Yeah, the spot’s called “1984.”  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 53.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yesterday, the day after it airs-- once--the publisher of Ad Week calls it the best commercial of all time. Of all time. And it is and if anyone ever does one better it’s gonna be Chiat/Day who the board wanted to replace and it’s gonna be Lee Clow who the board thought was out of his mind. Now listen to this, you ready? The “1984” ad starts playing on the screen--we’re seeing from behind--and as soon as it starts the CROWD ROARS.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah speaking of the ad--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They wanted to fire Lee Clow.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Did we use skinheads as extras? A couple of people have told me that.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: We paid skinheads? I have skinheads on my payroll?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (beat) Not currently I don’t think, but--

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They had a look he wanted.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: The skinheads.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: ‘Kay let’s keep that to ourselves ‘cause it might offend some of our customers.  23 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 54. 23

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Which ones?

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: All the ones who aren’t skinheads.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: My point is they didn’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: They did not.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They didn’t get it, they didn’t like it, they tried to pull it, they were wrong, we were right and that boardroom is a big bowl of scares-the-living-shit-outta-me.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: I’m running your pass blocking on the board. Who else knows?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Who else knows what?

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: That we paid terrorists to be in our TV commercial.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: John--

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: They were wrong about the ad but it’s a good board, they’re good people.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Their only problem, their problem is that they’re people. People...the nature of people...is something to be overcome.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (pause) When I was running Pepsi we had a lot of success focusing on 18-to-55 year olds who aren’t members of violent hate (groups).  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 55.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) I get it.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: You're not surrounded by enemies. (beat) We’re almost there. About two more minutes of quarterly reports. They listen to Markkula’s remarks a moment...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) Chrisann came and she brought Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: I had a hunch.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m going back and forth on the Dylan. I might quote a different verse.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: What are the choices?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: “For the loser now will be later to win,” which is what we have now.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Or?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: “It’1l soon shake your windows and rattle your walls”.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: We're leading a geek revolution and not the French Revolution, what else?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: “Come mothers and fathers throughout the land. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 56.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And don’t criticize what you can’t understand. Your sons and your daughters--”

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: “--are beyond your command”, I just lost a hundred bucks to Andy Hertzfeld. He said you'd change it to that verse. We’ve got 45 seconds left and I want to use it to ask you a question. Why do people who were adopted feel like they were rejected instead of selected?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That came out of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: “Your sons and your daughters are beyond your command. Your old road is rapidly aging. So go fuck yourself ‘cause my name is Steve Jobs and the times, they are a- changin’”.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don’t feel rejected.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Very sure.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: ‘Cause it’s not like the baby is born and the parents look and say, “Nah, we’re not interested in this one.” On the other hand, someone did choose you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s a song about progress.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: It’s about destroying the past.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: As long as clocks work the past will destroy itself by being the past.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 57.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: No, you have to consciously get rid of it or the past will be the present as well. And STEVE’s so happy that someone’s articulated this--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes! I was (testing you)--

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (over) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That's exactly--see?--that’s exactly what--you'’re the only one-- God--that’s what I meant. You’re the only one who sees the world the way I do. (beat) What inspired Hertzfeld to make that bet?

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: He was warning me that being your father figure could be dangerous. I can start replacing the board with more Steve-friendly members.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) It’s having no control.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: You’re the company, you have control.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I wasn’t talking about the company. (beat) You find out that you were out of the loop when the most crucial events in your life were set in motion. As long as you have control...I don’t understand people who give it up. (beat) He said being a father figure to me was dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: He didn’t mean anything by it.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 58.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Keep your hundred bucks, I’m sticking with the first verse.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What the hell did he (mean by that?)

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (over) Nothing. (beat) I’m proud of you. He doesn’t get weepy but that always means a lot to STEVE

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thank you, boss.

dialogues.speaker: MARKKULA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s my pleasure to introduce my friend and the CEO of Apple, John Sculley.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: John?

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (turning back) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Lisa made a painting on the Mac.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: --and “The Times They Are a-Changin’” crashes in. But this isn’t Bob Dylan’s version--it’s a woman singing instead of an acoustic guitar it’s a slightly fuller and slightly more up-tempo arrangement. It’s not a Vietnam-er protest song but a more contemporary and literal statemen We listen to the beginning of the song with the screen in black before we--

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 59.

dialogues.speaker: PETER JENNINGS
dialogues.text: As the song continues--

dialogues.speaker: PETER JENNINGS
dialogues.text: We turn to “Money Matters” and Barry Peterson.

dialogues.speaker: BARRY PETERSON
dialogues.text: The Macintosh, Apple’s near- mythological home computer, has gotten off to a rocky start in its battle with industry-titan IBM. With sales originally projected to be a million in the first quarter, Apple has sold only 35,000 of the user-friendly machines in the month since it’s been available to consumers.

dialogues.speaker: DAN RATHER
dialogues.text: Apple Computers closed two of its factories today in the wake of disappointing sales for what was to be its new flagship computer, the Macintosh.

dialogues.speaker: LOCAL NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: Industry experts sight the lack of available software for the Mac as a reason for its failure to catch on with the public.

dialogues.speaker: BILL TAHILL, (INDUSTRY EXPERT)
dialogues.text: The insistence by Steve Jobs that it have what’s called end to end control, which is a way of saying that it’s not compatible with most outside software or hardware, is the Shakespearian flaw in a machine that had potential.  27 28 29 30 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 60.

dialogues.speaker: TECH EXPERT
dialogues.text: You know how many Macs were sold last month? Five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: PETER JENNINGS
dialogues.text: Apple announced today that it will close down another one of its factories, this one in Dallas. For more on that we go to Barry Peterson and “Money Matters.”

dialogues.speaker: DAN RATHER
dialogues.text: In a move that surprised some but not all on Wall Street and in the high tech corridors of Northern California, the board of directors of Apple Computer voted today to fire its cofounder, Steve Jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The Times They Are a-Changin’” continues--—

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: 1988 San Francisco Opera House The Opera House holds twice as many people as the Flint Auditorium did and the crowd to get in this morning seems three times as large as for the Mac launch. There are loc news vans parked in front, photographers and press with credentials around their necks and of course the giant cr waiting to get into the lobby, which is already jammed. Huge banners hung from flagpoles tell us we’re here for t launch of NeXT and it’s first product--The Cube. (V.0.)

dialogues.speaker: THE CHANCE WON'T COME AGAIN
dialogues.text: (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 61.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: (V.0.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: FOR THE WHEEL'S STILL IN SPIN
dialogues.text: AND THERE'S NO TELLIN’ WHO THAT IT'S NAMIN’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE’s alone on stage in a pool of light. His hair’s a little shorter now and his haircuts cost a few hundred bu But the real difference is a lighthearted air--an easy se of humor. On a beautifully lit table sits a black cube shrouded in black cloth and next to it sits a vase of flowers. Slides change on the screen in back of Steve to accompany what h saying.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Three thousand colleges and universities in the United States alone. Over 45 thousand departments, over 600 thousand faculty members, over 12 million students. Stanford’s annual budget’s 750 million dollars and growing. The University of Michigan- -over a billion dollars and growing. Ohio State, Cal, Colorado, UCLA, Georgia Tech--these are Fortune 500 companies disguised as George? STEVE’s calling out to GEORGE COATES, the creative direct of the presentation.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (calling) Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The focus seems kind of sharp.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: On the slide?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The floor, the pin spot.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 62.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think we want sharp focus.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It looks like I’m Steve the Magnificent.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You can’t see it from your angle.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’ve seen it from every seat in the building and from too many of them does it look like I’m about to produce a silk scarf. Don’t take it personally, I’m just not a fan of the circus aesthetic.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (calling out) Alright, let’s hold here. (to STEVE) We’re gonna have to go up and re- focus the instruments.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pointing up) Just one--the 30’s fine. JOANNA’s walked on stage and is, of course, four years ol

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: While we’re holding there are well- wishers in the VIP room. They start heading off stage--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I like the circus, I love the circus, but why does it still look like that?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: And Woz is here.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Those performers are unbelievable. They have mastered incredibly hard albeit not very useful skills--I don’t know what the hell goes on in the Ukraine--and it should be presented in a more--I’m gonna revolutionize the circus.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 63.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Why are you in a good mood?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I'm always in a good mood.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: John Sculley’s here too. STEVE doesn’t like hearing that and he takes his frustrat out on the door as he pushes it open and they walk into--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: It’s nice that he’s here.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No more blue tents with yellow stars, no more costumes and transvestite make-up--a black stage, white light, and I'll be perfectly honest I’m back and forth on clowns, you know why?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: And Andy Hertzfeld. You have to see them, they want to pay their respects.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Not one of them has ever made me laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You have to see them anyway.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I was talking about clowns, you unassimilated commie.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Look--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: If they really wished me well they'd keep it to themselves.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Can I tell you something?  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 64.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don’t think they do wish me well but I’m alright with that. I’m over Apple. I got over the Mac and Woz and Sculley the same way you get over your high school sweetheart. Build a new one.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Can I tell you something?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You said you wouldn’t compete with them and you designed a computer specifically for the education market which they putatively own so I think it’s cool they're here.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They're suing me.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Still it was nice they came.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They're not being magnanimous, they want it to look like an amicable divorce. History doesn’t remember Joe DiMaggio kindly for dumping Marilyn. JOANNA makes a suppressed but loud sound while shutting h eyes and shaking her fists at God.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s your problem?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t know but I’m sure it can be traced back to you. You know I’m the one who has to explain you to people. $100,000 to Paul Rand for a corporate logo when we didn’t even know what our company made. A $650,000 mold for the Cube because God forbid the angles are 90.1 instead of 90.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 65.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I forbid the angles be 90.1 instead of 90. That box could be on display at the Guggenheim and you're forgetting about the number of coats of paint.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: On the Cube or the factory? As if customers are out there thinking, “You know I'd buy that thing except I’m not sure I like the color of the walls at their plant in Fort Worth.”

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You're very funny for someone with no imagination.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Don’t give them a reason to say to the press you have a chip on your shoulder, will you do that for me?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don’t have a chip on my shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (trying not to laugh) Okay, but don’t give them a reason to say you do.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: That’s the right attitude.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s not an att-- (beat) They’re gonna call me back in a minute to look at the light.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Get one out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Yeah?  32 33 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JOANNA’s starting to try to figure something out. Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: One more thing.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No questions from the press after.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: No--why?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Until I have better answers. No press avail. Somebody asks where I am, you just saw me and I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: How long do you think that’s going to work?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, how good are you at your job?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Tell me what I don’t know. I mean it, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (pause) Okay. Who do you want first?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Bring me the face of Steve Wozniak. STEVE walks into-- INT. STEVE’S OPERA HOUSE DRESSING ROOM - CONTINUOUS --where he walks to a small refrigerator bottle of water. He turns around and--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Aagh! and takes out a 66. 32 33  33 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 67.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: --reacts to the sight of LISA, now nine years old, who he clearly didn’t know was in the room. LISA is studiously measuring the sides of the NeXT Comput the black cube, with a plastic ruler. She has a Sony Walk on her waist with the headphones around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Hang on.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I thought you went to school?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Hang on.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You were supposed to go to school an hour ago, I thought you left.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I didn’t wake up my mom on time this morning. It’s happened before too. I wake up with the alarm and then I get dressed and eat breakfast but then sometimes I forget to see what time it is after that.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) Why doesn’t your mom just set her own alarm clock?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: It’s one of my chores. STEVE hates hearing this but doesn’t want to get into it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) Well I don’t understand what that has to do with why you're still-- where’s your mother?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: She went to find a pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: An hour ago she said-- LISA raises her hand.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 68.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t have to raise your hand.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: You said it was off by a little.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I just measured it. STEVE looks at her a second and then goes to the door and pops his head out, looking for help--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (calling) Joanna!

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Exactly a foot on all four sides.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: There are six sides but you’re not supposed to be here right now.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: We know if four sides are equal to each other the other two are equal as well.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What grade are you in?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Fourth.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You're nowhere near taking geometry.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: It’s just logic.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The top, bottom, right and left are about a millimeter shorter than the front and back.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: They’re not, I measured them.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 69.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Lisa, I’m kind of an expert in design and that’s a 20 cent ruler, you think there’s a chance it could be off? LISA thinks about it a moment...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (pause) If I had another ruler I could measure the ruler but I really doubt (it’s off).

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: When your mother--

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: ‘Cause it’s a ruler.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (beat) --comes back, you have to go to school.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Why is it off?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I just said?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ‘Cause sometimes it seems like you just keep saying what you want without listening.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I'm listening. There’s a silence for a moment...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Is there something you need?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: No. Another uncomfortable silence...  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 70.

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) Why isn’t it a perfect cube?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You've asked me before.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I forgot what it is.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s an optical anomaly. To the human eye a perfect cube doesn’t look like a cube so we made it roughly a millimeter shorter than a foot on two sides.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What’s an anomaly?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You've asked me that before too, I don’t know why you do that. LISA doesn't really know what to say...because she’s nine

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) It’s an exception, something that doesn’t fit a pattern. There’s a knock on the door--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have to go to school. (calling) Come in. JOANNA opens the door and she and WOZ enter--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I think you two have met.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey man. Woz Hello old friend.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You look well.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 71.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: woz So do you, so do you.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: And they're telling me George is ready for you to look at the focus.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to WOZ) Take a walk with me. woz Is this Lisa?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. woz This can’t be Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It is. Woz (indicating small) Lisa’s this big.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They get taller. Come on. woz Do you remember me?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: She doesn’t. woz I’m your dad’s friend, Steve Wozniak.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I apologize, I don’t remember you. woz (pause) You're very polite.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Woz? woz Yeah.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 72.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WOZ heads out the door--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to JOANNA) Chrisann’s at a pay phone. (quietly meaning LISA) Would you watch Lisa until--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Yeah. STEVE joins WOZ out in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where they make their way to the stage. woz It’s a madhouse out there.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Good turnout. woz Great turnout.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. woz “Insanely great.”

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Insanely great. woz You know this is the first time ever we haven’t played for the same team. It’s like you’re releasing your first solo album. I appreciate your inviting me to the launch.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I just want to wipe the slate clean. woz That’s exactly what I want. That’s why I came backstage. I want you to know I’1l be out there with you.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 73.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Any chance I could get you to go out there instead of me? woz I love you, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I love you too, Woz. woz You know--some things were said--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They were. woz They were. (pause) I’m clumsy at this. I guess--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They were said in public. woz (beat) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They were published. You knew you were talking to a reporter from Fortune, right? You weren’t tricked? woz No.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pointing) Watch your step. woz Look, I don’t even remember exactly what I said. I know it was--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (no problem) “Steve can be an insulting and hurtful guy.” woz Yeah.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 74.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (no problem) “I look forward to a great product and I wish him success-- woz Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (problem) “--but his integrity I cannot trust.” Wait here a second. They’re backstage now and STEVE walks onto the stage wher there’s a new pool of light waiting for him. We stay on W backstage for a moment, who now understands that Steve's version of wiping the slate clean and his are two differe things. GEORGE COATES calls from out in the house--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good? STEVE looks at the floor, at the edges of the pool of lig

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Good. Where do you want to pick it up?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The thesaurus.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A word that’s sometimes used to describe me--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hold please, they’re not cued up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We've got about 10 minutes before we have to clear the house.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I doubt we’re starting on time.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I promise you we are.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We still have to get through--  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 75.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: We make computers, we’re--I’ve had this conversation before--we'’re starting on time. The giant screen behind Steve is showing the NexT desktop STEVE demonstrates the thesaurus feature.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A word that’s sometimes used to describe me is “mercurial.”

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hold for laugh.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Let's look at the dictionary definitions. (scrolling to it) “Of or relating to or born under the planet Mercury.” (scrolling down) I think the third one is what they mean. STEVE glances offstage where he sees that LISA is now watching a few feet from WOZ.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Characterized by unpredictable changeableness of mood.”

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hold for laugh.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: If we scroll down the thesaurus, though, we see the antonym is “saturnine.” By simply double- clicking on it we immediately look that up in the dictionary and here it is: “Cold and steady in moods. Slow to act or change. Of a gloomy or surly disposition.”

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hold for laugh.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 76.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: So I don’t think “mercurial” is so bad after all.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Let’s jump to 141.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Gimme just a second. STEVE walks to the wings--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to LISA) It’s against the law for you not to be in school.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: My mom said I could watch.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Where is she? STEVE leads LISA and WOZ back into--

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Why did mercurial end up not being a bad word?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Do you remember asking me that the night before last when you were having dinner at my house?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I forgot the answer.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The word that was the opposite of mercurial was bad, which meant mercurial was good.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I don’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I think you do get it.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I don’t.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 77.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ‘Cause we also talked about it when you came to the rehearsal last week.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Why aren't the angles straight?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The angles?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: On the Cube.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The angles are straight.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I meant why aren’t they straight on other things?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Why does it feel like you’re working me?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Woz? Why aren’t the angles straight on other things? woz (to LISA) When the manufacturers make things with 90 degree angles, they cheat the angle a little bit--89, 91--so that it’s easier to get the object out of the mold. Like getting a cake out of a pan. But on your dad's new computer he insisted the angles be exactly 90 degrees.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Why? woz He’s a perfectionist.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Cool.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 78.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Some people don’t mean cool when they use that word. woz (to LISA) I did. STEVE opens the door to -- 36 INT. STEVE’S DRESSING ROOM - CONTINUOUS 36 --where CHRISANN is waiting.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I thought you guys left an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISANN
dialogues.text: She wants to watch her father’s presentation.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to LISA) Wait in here, I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (to CHRISANN) I saw the thesaurus. STEVE closes the door behind her and stands alone in the with WOZ--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Were you pressured to do it? woz (pause) What do you mean? STEVE looks around...then WOZ follows him through a doubl door marked “Authorized Personnel Only” and into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty chairs and empty music stands are arranged in a sem circle facing an empty conductor’s podium. STEVE looks around at it for a moment...WOZ doesn’t reall know what they’re doing there. STEVE begins walking aroun slowly...  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 79.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Check it out. It’s the orchestra pit for the San Francisco Opera. woz Was I pressured to do it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I once met Seiji Ozawa at Tanglewood. Thunderous conductor. Ungodly artfulness and nuance. And I asked him what exactly a conductor does that a metronome can’t do. Surprisingly-- woz --he didn’t beat the shit out of you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (laughing at Woz’s joke) That's right. No, he said, “The musicians play their instruments. I play the orchestra.” woz That feels like something that sounds good but doesn’t mean anything.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Markkula, Sculley, did they ask you to slag me off in the press? woz I had reason (to be angry).

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) Did they? woz Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: But they asked you to talk. woz Apple was under siege, you’d just left the company, somebody had to talk to the press.  37 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 80.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (old time producer) I'm right here, Woz, the company left me. woz I begged you, I begged you. The Apple II accounted for 70% of revenue, what’d you think was gonna happen? You didn’t care enough about the Apple II or the Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Let's be really clear, I didn’t care at all about the Apple II or the Lisa. woz I wasn’t pressured to do it. What I said to the press was an honest if tempered reflection of what I believed.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Woz? woz Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What the fuck is on your wrist? woz You want to know?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I literally can’t wait. woz Everyone’s going to be wearing this in 10 years. It’s a Nixie Watch made using Nixie tubes. woz is showing STEVE his watch. It’s a chunky thing that gives a large digital read-out of the time. The thing is the numbers look exactly like the kind of numbers that ar a time-bomb when it counts down in the movies.

dialogues.speaker: WOZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is actually 40-year-old technology--cold cathode tubes and they’re running on 140 volts. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 81.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: woz (CONT'D) I tilt my wrist 45 degrees and it’s right there--hours and minutes--the way our minds work.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Do me a favor--set the watch ahead like you're on a plane and changed time zones. woz Not a problem. WOZ unscrews the face of the watch, the MacGyver-bomb num look even worse as WOZ starts to press tiny buttons with tip of his pen.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, flight attendant? The man next to me would appear to be detonating a bomb. WOZ stops... woz (pause) You think it looks like a bomb?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Even right now I’m not a hundred percent sure it isn’t. woz (pause) Maybe once people get used to--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Nope. They sit in silence a moment... woz (pause) I was angry. You were saying things about the Apple II and the way you were treating the (team)--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) Woz--you get a free pass for life, okay? (beat--standing) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 82.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve gotta get back onstage, we've got like two minutes of rehearsal time left. STEVE heads for the door but he’s stopped by-- woz Do you understand how condescending that just was? Maybe you (don’t, maybe) --

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) I don’t want to see you dragged off an airplane in plastic handcuffs, how is that-- woz I get a free pass for life? From you? You’re the one who gives out the passes?! You give ‘em to me?!!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You're gonna have a stroke, li’l buddy. woz What did you do?! What did you do?! Why has Lisa not heard of me?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Shit, man, how many fourth-graders have heard of you? woz You can’t write code. You’re not an engineer, you’re not a designer, you can’t put a hammer to a nail. I built the circuit board, the graphical interface was stolen from Xerox PARC, Jeff Raskin was the leader of the Mac team before you threw him off his own project... everything! Somebody else designed the box! So how come 10 times ina day I read Steve Jobs is a genius? What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I play the orchestra. And you’re a good musician. (pointing) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 83.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You sit right there. You’re the best in your row. woz I came here to clear the air. You know why I came here?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Didn’t you just (answer that?) woz (over) I came here ‘cause you’re gonna get killed. Your computer is going to fail. You had a college and university advisory board telling you they need a powerful workstation for 2 to 3 thousand, you've priced NexT at 6500, which doesn’t include the optional three thousand-dollar hard drive which people will discover isn’t optional because the optical disk is too weak to do anything and the twenty five hundred dollar laser printer brings the total to twelve-thousand dollars and in the entire world, you are the only person who cares that it’s housed in a perfect cube. You're gonna get killed and I came here to stand next to you while that happens because that’s what friends do, that’s what men do, I don't need your pass. We go back so don’t talk to me like I’m other people. I’m the only one who knows that this guy here is someone you invented. I’m standing by you ‘cause that perfect cube that does nothing is about to be the single biggest failure in the history of personal computing. STEVE wants to tear into WOZ and he considers it for a qu moment but instead of doing that he says this...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) Tell me something else I don’t know. STEVE opens the door and walks out into--  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOANNA’s waiting.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Back on stage?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: We're out of time. They’ve got to mop the stage and open the house. STEVE looks at her...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) If it crashes it crashes, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You'll make a joke.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I‘1l make a joke.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: If it crashes it crashes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s a good slogan. “NeXT: If it Crashes it Crashes.”

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
