dialogues.text: I don’t remember. We were talking and I said--it was pretty much what I just said, that it certainly couldn’t hurt.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You didn’t say Lisa needed a strong male role model?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (pause) I did. (pause) I think it’s a miracle she’s not robbing banks with the Symbionese Liberation Army. There is no reason in the world why she should be nice. But she is. So I helped. Because somebody had to.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) I'll wire the money to you this afternoon. ANDY gets up and heads to the door...

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You threatened me a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: A long time ago. You threatened me once.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: People are attracted to people with talent and people without it find that threatening. Maybe you should see a therapist. It certainly couldn’t hurt.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (pause) I meant you literally threatened me. At Flint, right before the Mac launch. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ANDY exits Shooting Script 03/19/15 149. 96

dialogues.speaker: ANDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was recompiling, I was trying to debug the voice demo and you said if I couldn’t find a solution you’d call me out in front of the audience.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Did it say “Hello”?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It did.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No need to thank me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (beat) Why do you want people to dislike you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don’t want people to dislike me. I'm indifferent to whether they dislike me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Well...since it doesn’t matter? I always have.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) Really? I’ve always liked you a lot. That’s too bad.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Knock ‘em dead.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thank you. STEVE stands there a moment...then launches into a practi run of a section of the presentation so he can wipe away just happened.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is remarkable, what's hard to fathom but true is that for a given clock rate a power PC chip is twice as fast as a Pentium II chip. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 150.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In other words a 266 Megahertz G3 is twice as fast as a 266 Megahertz Pentium II or a 266 G3 is equal to about 500 Megahertz. Take a look at BYTE Magazine's BYTE Marks, the gold standard for-- There’s a KNOCK at the door--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come in. JOANNA enters.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I sent someone into the lobby. They found her and--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: She said she’d rather not come back.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: That was it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (heading for the door) I’m going out there myself.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You can’t. You can’t, you can’t. It’ll be a scene out of Hard Day's Night.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) Will you-- JOEL PFORZHEIMER knocks on the open door--

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Hey Joel.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Andy said it was okay to come back.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Andy Cunningham.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to JOANNA) I need one of them to change their name, I can’t do this forever.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You call Andy Cunningham Andrea.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter what I call them. I know who I’m talking about when I'm talking. I need everyone else to call them different names. (to JOEL) Gimme one second. STEVE takes JOANNA out into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and out of hearing distance where he speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Go get her for me please. I just talked to Andy...Hertzfeld...and I’m just trying to scrub this out of my brain with Drano but I do want to talk to Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (whispering) Yeah, just stay cool. 151. 96 97 JOANNA heads down the corridor and STEVE watches her go. Without turning around, JOANNA points to the two doors as passes them--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointing) Stage. Parking lot.  97 98 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 152.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thank you. He goes back into-- INT. STEVE’S DRESSING ROOM - CONTINUOUS 98

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I'm feeling good, Joel, how about you?

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: I don’t think I could be in your business. It changes too quickly.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well I’d hang on ‘cause yours is about to start changing pretty quickly too.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: This is the third time in 14 years I’m writing about you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) What do you think so far? ANDREA CUNNINGHAM sticks her head in the door--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Avie’s asking for you, he has a new shark slide.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Okay. (to JOEL) You want to come backstage for a second?

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Sure. They head out into--  99 100 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 153.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall is lined with blown up photographs of Ghandi, Jo Lennon, Louis Armstrong, etc.--all from the “Think Differ campaign.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: (pointing to a photo) Who's this one?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Alan Turing. He single handedly won World War II and for an encore invented the computer but he won’t be part of the campaign.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: ‘Cause you just had to ask me who he was. STEVE opens the door and they walk into-- INT. BACKSTAGE AREA — CONTINUOUS 100 --where AVIE and his ENGINEERS are doing last minute runs adjustments on the iMacs that'll be running the demo in a minutes. And we can HEAR the CROWD out in the house...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to AVIE) Can I see a new shark? AVIE hits a key and the screen fills with a picture of a PowerBook G3 Laptop and a great white shark with its teet bared.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like it better than the old shark.

dialogues.speaker: AVIE
dialogues.text: Sharks.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Sharks.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 154.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: How many sharks did you go through?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A couple.

dialogues.speaker: AVIE
dialogues.text: This is the 39th.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pointing to JOEL) We’re on the record.

dialogues.speaker: AVIE
dialogues.text: 39 sharks.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: AVIE
dialogues.text: You know what’s special about this shark?

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AVIE
dialogues.text: No, I’m really asking ‘cause it looks exactly like the other 38 sharks to me.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Let me see it with the cue. From the profile.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: This is Cue 92B.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (reciting) This is a side profile here. And this is what it looks like from the back. And one more thing: It eats Pentium notebooks as a light snack. (good) This is the shark, I really like it. Nobody gets it right the first time but I should have been shown this shark 15, 20 fish ago.

dialogues.speaker: AVIE
dialogues.text: You probably were.  100 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 155. 100

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Lock it in.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: Ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: He killed himself by taking a bite of a poison Apple. Alan Turing.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. There should be statues of that man. His name should be on the lips of schoolchildren.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: The rainbow flag Apple with a bite taken out, that’s where it came from?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No, we picked it off a list of friendly sounding words. But wouldn’t it be great if that had been the story behind it? (beat) Anyway, I can’t use him in the campaign. Woz, sitting out in the house, calls up to the stage-- woz (calling) Steve. STEVE looks out... woz (CONT'D) I kind of liked the last shark.

dialogues.speaker: AVIE
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Fuck you. woz I wanted to ask you a favor.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: My friend, a long time ago you asked me a favor before a product launch and I said no. You wanted me to acknowledge the Apple II and I--  100 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 156. 100 woz Hang on. If you’re about to say you were wrong I want to prepare this reporter.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I was one hundred percent right and you were spectacularly wrong but I still owe you a favor so name it. woz Steve?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: But it can’t be about acknowledging the Apple II team. woz Acknowledge the Apple II team.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) How about in private? woz No.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Is this a prank (‘cause)-- woz (over) No.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: --I'm trying to remember that a 300 Megahertz G3 chip is equal to a (600 Megahertz Pentium II and)-- woz (over) Just the top guys. STEVE searches his mind a moment for the path of least resistance when he sees JOANNA come backstage--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Okay? woz Yeah.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 157.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: One second. STEVE goes over to JOANNA--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (quietly) She said she’d rather not.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: She's sitting with her friends and she said she’d rather not come back.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Okay, tell her--take her aside, I don’t want to embarrass her in front of her friends, but tell her I just scared the shit out of Andy and this time nobody's paying her fuckin’ -- JOANNA gives him a look--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright, don’t say that. But do your thing where you sound old and wise because of the broad, tragic European canvas of your life.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You know I wasn’t born in a 19th Century shtetl, right?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Please tell her it’s important. STEVE goes back to WOZ as JOANNA heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL
dialogues.text: Everything alright?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. STEVE continues to WOZ--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are people around (here, man, including--)  100 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: woz (over) I know.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A member of (the press) woz (over) I see him.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Woz-- woz Just the top guys. The ones who are getting laid off.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Listen. Okay? Last year Apple lost one billion dollars. I don’t even know how that’s possible. You were less than 90 days from being insolvent. I had three different accountants try to explain it to me. The whole place has to be streamlined. woz Start with two of the accountants.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I started--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Joel, come with me, we're gonna--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Leave him right there. (back to WOZ) I started with the Apple II team, because we don’t, you know, make that anymore. woz Just acknowledge the top guys.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Have a mimosa and (relax). woz You will not blow me off right now! The top (guys--) 158. 100  100 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 159. 100

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) There are no top guys! On the Apple II team there are no top guys. They’re B Players and B Players discourage the A Players and I want the A Players at Apple and not Dell. woz They’re not B Players and I’ma better judge of (that than you are).

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) Less than 90 days to insolvency. In part because somebody thought the Newton wasn’t a box of garbage.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Joel--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Leave him! woz I'm talking about--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You guys designed and shipped a little box of garbage while I was gone. woz --I'm talking about the Apple II which isn’t just a crucial part of this company’s history, it’s a crucial part of the history of personal computing--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: For a time. woz --and the least you can do if you're gonna downsize these people--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: They're gonna live in the biggest houses of anyone on the unemployment line.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 160.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: woz --is to acknowledge them, just acknowledge them and the--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: There is no God. woz --and the Apple II during this launch.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (resolute) This is a new animal. woz This whole place was built by the Apple II. You were built by the Apple II.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact I was destroyed by the Apple II and its open system so that hackers and hobbyists could build ham radios or something and then it nearly destroyed Apple when you spent all your money on it and developed a grand total of no new products. woz The (Newton).

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (over) The little box of garbage? You guys came up with the Newton and you, like, want people to know that? This is a product launch, it’s not a luncheon, and the last thing I want to do is connect the iMac-- woz --to the only successful product this company’s ever made? I’m sorry to be blunt it happens to be the truth. The Lisa was a failure. The Macintosh was a failure. I don’t like talking like this but I’m tired of being Ringo when I know I was John.  100 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 161. 100

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Everybody loves Ringo! woz And I'm tired of being patronized by you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You think John became John by winning a raffle, Woz? You think he tricked somebody or hit George Harrison over the head? He was John because he was John. woz He was John because he wrote “Ticket to Ride” and I wrote the Apple II.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: (calling out) Everybody, I want to clear the--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Nobody moves! You made a beautiful board which, by the way, you were willing to give out for free so don’t tell me how you built Apple. If it weren’t for me you'd be the easiest “A” at Homestead High School. woz These people live and die by your praise and here’s your chance. Acknowledge that something good happened that you weren’t in the room for.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) No. Woz Steve, do it. It’s right. It’s just...it’s right.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Sorry but no. woz (pause) Then let me put it another way. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 162. 100

dialogues.speaker: WOZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t believe there’s a man who's done more to advance the democratization that comes with personal computing than I have but you've never had any respect for me, now why is that?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I'd at least consider the possibility that it’s because you've never had any for me. JOANNA’s come out in the house and sees what’s happening-

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on? woz Nothing. Thanks for your time.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (to STEVE) It’s done. She’s coming back. STEVE nods...then turns back to WOZ--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to WOZ) You came a half-inch from putting this company out of business, now who do I see about that? I’m letting you keep your job. You get a pass. woz When people used to ask me what the difference was between me and Steve Jobs I'd say Steve was the big picture guy and I liked a solid workbench. When people ask me what the difference is now I just say Steve’s an asshole. The things you make are better than you are, brother.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That’s the idea, brother. And knowing that?...That'’s the difference. woz (the end of this friendship) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 163.

dialogues.speaker: WOZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not binary. You can be decent and gifted at the same time. STEVE starts to walk away from WOZ but then turns around-

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Woz. (beat) I once asked Paul McCartney what made the Beatles sound like the Beatles and you know what he said? The drumming. woz Do you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) No, it was John. WOZ has waited years to say this and for all those years hoped he wouldn’t have to. woz Maybe one day you’1l make something and know for sure. ‘Cause the little box of garbage? Was one little box of garbage more than you've ever made in your life. STEVE holds a moment, nods and heads over to JOANNA, who’ clocked this whole last exchange.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: He didn’t mean it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah he did.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: He’s a temperamental guy.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No he’s not. (pause) It’s like 5 minutes before every launch everyone goes to a bar, gets drunk and tells me what they really think.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (pause) She's coming to your dressing room.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 164.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They head out into--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I told you to make up with Lisa, I didn’t say you had to settle every blood feud you have. Who lives that long?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The last time blood feuds weren't settled I lost the cover of Time. Though for the life of me I still don’t know what the hell Dan Kottke was mad at me about.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Kottke didn’t lose you the cover of Time.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Of course he did.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Would you like me to demonstrate your capacity to be wrong when you're certain you’re right?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Dan Kottke told Michael Moritz that I was denying-- They walk into-- 102 INT. STEVE’S DRESSING ROOM - CONTINUOUS 102

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Do you remember the cover?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Of Time?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: What was it?  102 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: STEVE take STEVE’s a Shooting Script 03/19/15 165. 102

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: What was on the cover?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A computer.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: No, it was a sculpture of a computer. It was a sculpture. Time would have had to have commissioned it months in advance. (beat) You were never in the conversation for Man of the Year. Nobody lost you anything. So what else are you sure about?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) I don’t know how I could have missed that.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Reality distortion. s this in...it’s really rocked his world...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) No seriously.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Seriously. little shaken up...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) I don’t know how I could have missed that. JOANNA looks at STEVE silently. She’s not going to help h this time. Then--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Don’t try to win an argument with Lisa. Just say you were wrong. A kid should hear their dad say, “I was wrong” once in a while.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 166.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There’s a KNOCK on the door...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause--then calling) Come on in, honey. The door opens a little and SCULLEY sticks his head in--

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: It’s not honey. There’s a moment of shock as STEVE and SCULLEY take in th sight of each other. Sculley’s always been a handsome man healthy, well-scrubbed, Connecticut guy--but he was sent Florida much too young. And he’s been living a secluded l as the guy who traded Babe Ruth. STEVE can see that.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (pause) John, get in, get out of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: I was taken in a side entrance. I’1ll go out the same way, no one’1l see me. (beat) How are you, Joanna?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I’m good, John. I’m just surprised to see you.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: I know. You look well.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I looked better 20 hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: We all did.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Everyone here really appreciates the quote you gave Forbes, you didn’t have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: If you want I can slip you in the back once the house lights go out.  102 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: I’m just here to say good luck.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Okay. (to STEVE) You've just got a couple of minutes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Would you try to find--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Yeah. JOANNA gives SCULLEY a kiss on the cheek, then wipes off lipstick marks. She loves that he came.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re a good man, John. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: So I brought you a present. SCULLEY hands STEVE a box...STEVE smiles...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A Newton.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t take it out of the box. You'll be able to sell it. Which is more than I can say. (pause) Everything alright there?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (beat) What? Yeah. No, it’s just something Joanna pointed out to me. I missed something so obvious about--it doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (pause) Look, Wall Street's gonna sit back and wait to see how you do as CEO, don’t let any fluctuation bother you for the first 12 months. Day traders are gonna respond to every-- I don’t need to school you.  102 103 104 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 168. 102

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (meaning the Newton) Is this your way of telling me I shouldn't have killed the Newton?

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Well you shouldn’t have killed it for spite. That’s bad business, don’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unimpressive-looking Mediterranean restaurant in Berke STEVE and SCULLEY sit at a booth.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Alright 1957, and IBM passes up the chance to buy a young company that’s just developed a technology called xerography.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. STEVE’S DRESSING ROOM - DAY 104

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) I was given back.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you’ve always been interested in my adoption history but you said it’s not like someone looked at me and gave me back but that is what happened.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (pause) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: QUICK CUT TO
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 169.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Then 10 years later, DEC invents the mini-computer and IBM dismisses it as too small to do serious computing.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: They weren’t close enough to the future to see it by then?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: DEC becomes a billion dollar corporation and IBM decides they should maybe get into the computer business. The owner of the restaurant, a balding Syrian-American na JANDALI comes over to the table.

dialogues.speaker: JANDALI
dialogues.text: Mr. Steve Jobs.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Jandali, say hello to John Sculley. Jandali owns this place and John’s the CEO of Pepsi but I’m trying to get him to move to Cupertino and put a dent in the universe.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: You never told me that.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A lawyer couple adopted me first and then gave me back after a month. They changed their mind.

dialogues.speaker: JANDALI
dialogues.text: (to SCULLEY) Do you eat vegan as well?  107 108 109 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 170. 107

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: No, I‘’1l eat anything.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you start us off with a Mediterranean lettuce salad with purslane, mint, cucumbers--

dialogues.speaker: JANDALI
dialogues.text: And the sumac-lemon vinaigrette?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Thanks. JANDALI heads away as STEVE continues--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ten years later, 1977, and another young company called Apple invents the first personal computer--

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: --and IBM dismisses it as unimportant to their business.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Then my parents adopted me. My biological mother had stipulated that whoever took me had to be college educated, wealthy and Catholic. Paul and Clara Jobs were none of those things so my biological mother wouldn’t sign the adoption papers.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: In ‘81 the Apple II becomes the world’s most popular computer and now IBM gets into the game with the PC.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 171.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Apple and IBM each invest upwards of 50 million in R&D and another 50 million in advertising.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: It’s a shake down. They want to get rid of the weaker companies.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The weaker companies are going bankrupt. IBM wants it all.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: There was a legal battle that went on for a while and my mother said she refused to love me for the first year, you know in case they had to give me back.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: You can’t refuse to love someone, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah it turns out you can.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: And now IBM’s got its guns trained on you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Apple is the only thing standing between Blue and industry domination.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: You said you were going to tell me what you have in the testing stage.  111 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 172. 111

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The most efficient animal on the planet is a condor. The most inefficient animals on the planet are humans. But a human with a bicycle becomes the most efficient animal. And the right computer--a friendly, easy computer that isn’t an eyesore but rather sits on your desk with the beauty of a tensor lamp--the right computer will be a bicycle for the mind. A beautiful object--perfect geometry, perfect finish, something you want to look at and have in your home. Flawless. And then a personal computer becomes an interpersonal computer. And what if instead of it being in the right hands, it was in everyone’s hands? Everyone in the world.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (pause) We'd be talking about the most tectonic shift in the status quo since--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Ever.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (pause) And you're telling me you have the right computer?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It’s called the Macintosh. You and I can see to it that IBM doesn’t control the information age. We can see to it that Orwell was wrong. JANDALI comes over and sets down some food.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: There’s the spot. “1984 doesn’t have to be like ‘1984.'”

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Come be our CEO.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 173.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (pause) Yeah okay. STEVE and SCULLEY look at each other...the beginning of a great adventure.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) What the hell can a one month old do that’s so bad his parents give him back?

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Nothing. There’s nothing a one month old can do. (beat) Have you ever thought about trying to find your biological father?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’ve met my biological father. For that matter, so have you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see an earlier moment all over again--

dialogues.speaker: JANDALI
dialogues.text: Mr. Steve Jobs.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Jandali, say hello to John Sculley.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: 114 INT. STEVE’S DRESSING ROOM - SAME TIME 114 SCULLEY’s gone white...

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (long pause) You're kidding me.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 174.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I know. The odds were beyond astronomical.

dialogues.speaker: JANDALI
dialogues.text: Do you eat vegan as well?

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: 116 INT. STEVE’S DRESSING ROOM - SAME TIME 116

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: My sister found him.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Does he know?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No. In fact he bragged to Mona that Steve Jobs comes in the restaurant all the time.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (pause) You don’t want to--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Do you go to his rest--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No. Terrible food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE and a group of guests are having a boisterous conversation with STEVE joyfully eating something off som else’s plate--loving the food.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 175. 118 INT. STEVE’S DRESSING ROOM - SAME TIME 118

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t you think you should talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: He’d probably find a reason to sue me. SCULLEY sees STEVE clearly...maybe for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Ah...Steve.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (beat) John, if you're here about your legacy you need to form a line behind Wozniak.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Woz is gonna be fine. I’m the guy who fired Steve Jobs. (beat) Rich, college-educated and Catholic. There’s a KNOCK at the door--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Steve? It’s time.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I've gotta go. STEVE stops at the door--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause) Did I do this? Screw it up? SCULLEY takes a moment and then says something he’s not s he means--

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: Let’s let it go now. It has to be time.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) It was the stylus, John.  118 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 176.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I killed the Newton because of the stylus. If you're holding a stylus you can’t use the other five that are attached to your wrist. (pause) The things we could have done together.

dialogues.speaker: SCULLEY
dialogues.text: (pause) God, the things we could have done. STEVE opens the door and walks out into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hallway’s a little crowded now with Apple employees lining the walls including JOANNA. They’1l serve as an es backstage but right now, coming down the hall toward STEV --is LISA. At 19 she’s a beautiful young woman with a striking resemblance to her father. She’s wearing a coat has the same headphones around her neck that we saw her i when she was nine. She’s nothing like a stereotypical teenager--she’s without affect and only uses irony in ver small doses. We’re aware that she’s ill at ease and self- protective and uncomfortable. She walks down the hallway which is lined with “Think Different” posters that have a picture of the iMac. STEVE watches her walk toward him--he’s too worn out now have a real confrontation with her but he'll be slowly fo into it. He takes his arm to move her to the side of the corridor and he does his best to speak privately while al surrounded by people.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (speaking quietly in Lisa’s ear) I’m paying your tuition. Are you crazy? Of course I’m paying your tuition.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (quietly in his ear) I must have misunderstood when you said you weren’t paying my tuition.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 177.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You and your mom selling the house was a hostile thing to do and you (knew it).

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (over) She needed the money.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: She always needs the money.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: She needs a doctor, she has a sinus infection.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: She’s had the same sinus infection since 1988.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I’m gonna take care of my mother, I’m sorry if that angers you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: It does anger me ‘cause you’re a kid and it’s not your job to take care of your mother.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Is that how yours died? This just went to the next level and JOANNA’s just seen that...

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Guys step away please and give them some room. Everyone creates a little more space but total privacy is really impossible right now.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) When your mom is 90 and can’t feed herself you can take care of her. But right now she’s 45, perfectly healthy and can’t feed herself. You're supposed to work hard in school and be 19 and that’s it. I’ll take care of your mother.  119 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 178. 119

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Keep up the good work.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What the hell do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I was sent for.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Look, I bought her a house for seven-hundred thousand dollars, it’s worth twice that much today and she sold it for two magic rocks and a bowl of soup!

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: It was her house.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: She used that money to travel through Europe--

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: It was her money which you make her beg for.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (it’s time) Steve?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Oh don’t talk to me about--going to Andy and asking him for the money. That was so off-the-charts over (the line, I can’t even)--

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (over--calmly) I did not do that. Andy came to me. STEVE looks around at the dozen or so people that are too nearby for comfort--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Everybody have an opinion on this?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry guys-- (to STEVE) --in 30 seconds you're going to be late.  119 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 179. 119

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m callous ‘cause I’m not sending a Gulf Stream to the Pasteur Institute to fetch the finest sinus specialists in all the land?!

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Did I call you callous?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: She spends the money on antiques. And then sells them for a fraction of what she paid. And she does it with money I gave to her for you--

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Steve?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You came to me hysterical when you were (13, asking if you could live with me)--

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (over--calmly) I wasn’t hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: --because your mom was irrationally-

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Thirteen was the second time I asked you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: --screaming at you every day or not speaking to you for weeks at a time-- the stress of her life as a spiritual healer--

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I don’t believe I said you’re a bad guy but if I did I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Something happened to you at school. Some first semester core class that all freshman are required to take, some-—

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I read Time.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 180.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What? This has stopped STEVE in his tracks...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I have internet access at school, I read an old copy of Time and I asked my mom some questions about my family history. STEVE is frozen for a moment...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) That was...Time wrote a mangled piece of journal--you were never supposed to read that--

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I had two different Harvard statisticians try to reverse engineer the equation you came up with to prove that 28% of American men could be my father.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Honey-- LISA can’t help but raise her voice a little. She’s not someone who likes dramatics but she’s upset now. There’s way the others are going to be able to avoid hearing this

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: My mother may be a troubled woman but what’s your excuse? (beat) That’s why I’m not impressed with your story, dad. It’s that you knew and you didn’t do anything about it and that makes you an unconscionable coward. And not for nothin’ but “Think” is a verb making “Different” an adverb. You're asking people to “Think DifferentLY”. And you can talk about the Bauhaus movement and Braun and simplicity is sophistication and Issey Miyake uniforms and Bob Dylan lyrics all you want, but that thing-- (pointing at one of the posters of the iMac) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 181.

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --looks like Judy Jetson's Easy Bake Oven! LISA walks away and out the side door that goes to the parking lot. There’s a frozen silence for a moment before--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (pause) There is no way in the world that’s not my kid. STEVE looks at JOANNA who looks kindly back. After a mome ANDREA interrupts with--

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: (beat) Alright, here we go. Everyone begins to head to the door leading to the stage. see STEVE’s hand grab the door handle and turn it as we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE’s walked out the parking lot door to go after Lisa. can see JOANNA and ANDREA CUNNINGHAM and the others. We’r the side of the auditorium and while the lot is filled th are no people except LISA who's making her way to her car STEVE watches her go and then makes a decision--

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (shouting) Hey! LISA turns around.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (calling back) You’re gonna start late!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: You know what Lisa stood for?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What?  120 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 182. 120

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The computer, the Lisa, you know what it stood for?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I said that about the iMac, it’s not what I really think.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Behind my back, at the office, you know what it stood for?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Local Integrated System Architecture. I was five, why couldn’t you just lie?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I did. It stood for “Lisa. Colon. Invented Stupid Acronym.” (beat) Of course it was named after you, are you daffy! Local Integrated System Architecture doesn’t even mean anything, of course it was named after you.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (pause) Why did you say it wasn’t all those years?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (totally upfront and without hesitation) I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Why did you say you weren’t my father?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (not backing off it) Honey...I honestly don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: That’s a child’s answer.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (owning it) I’m poorly made. LISA stands there a moment, then checks her watch--  120 STEVE JOBS -—

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Shooting Script 03/19/15 183. 120

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: You can’t start late. It’s after nine.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I don’t get it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I know I didn’t want to be yoked to your mom but--

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: That’s just lame.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: And you can belittle my mother all you want but she always made dinner for me and she always took me to school.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Feeding you and taking you to school is kind of the baseline of parenting, Lisa, it’s actually a legal obligation. Don’t devalue yourself like that, don’t do that. (beat--finally) But you’re right, she did. And I didn’t. (pause) I‘m using “Different” as a noun, smartass. Like “Think Victory.” Or “Vote Freedom.”

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Vote Freedom?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. (pause) You're writing for the Crimson?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What?  120 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The Apple chapter of the Harvard Alumni Association tells me you're writing for the Crimson.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yeah, a little bit. Essays.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I'd like to read one.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: No, I mean now, I'd like to read one of your essays now.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: That’s--c’mon, you’ve got to go on stage.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Suit yourself but the iMac will not be launched until you give me one of your essays so the world is waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (pause) It’s not like I have one on me.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Somewhere in that backpack is one of your essays. Dump the contents on the ground and if I’m wrong I'll buy you a Cabriolet. 184. 120 LISA looks at him, not believing this...she unzips one of pockets of her backpack and things start falling out and she tries to collect them more things start falling out u everything’s on the ground. STEVE watches as LISA, unhurriedly, collects her things a puts them back. It’s going to take a while. STEVE just watches this, smiles and shakes his head...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (without looking up) I just spilled some...don’t laugh at me.  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 185.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I’m not. She finds the essay and holds it out. All she wants is fo her dad to be proud of her.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: It hasn't been published yet, I just finished but it’s a first draft and it reads like one.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (calling) Guys, I’m really sorry. STEVE takes the essay, crumpled and coffee-stained...STEV sees the byline on the essay--"LISA BRENNAN-JOBS.” STEVE can’t help but take in the sight of her using his n He’d stare at it forever if he wasn’t interrupted by--

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Dad. He looks up at her...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just read it after. You can give it your full attention.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Okay. But you should know that the Bay Area is strewn with the broken spirits of people who couldn't handle my full attention. And this makes LISA crack up. She really has a good laugh that makes her father smile. She picks up her backpack--

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Okay. LISA starts to walk off--  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 186.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling out) I’m gonna put music in your pocket. LISA turns around--

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A hundred songs. A thousand songs. Five hundred songs. Somewhere between five hundred and a thousand songs. Right in your pocket. Because I can’t stand looking at that inexplicable Walkman anymore. You're carrying around a brick playing a cassette tape. We’re not savages. So I’m gonna put a thousand songs in your pocket. And now we HEAR the musical intro to “Both Sides Now," bu it’s not the version we’re used to. This is the one Lisa describing when she was nine. It’s a beautiful male/femal duet with heartbreaking harmonies, more mature, wiser and haunted.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: You can do that?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Mm-hm. All I have to do really is wipe out the record business as we know it and we'll be all set. (pause) You want to watch from backstage?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Yeah. LISA joins her father and the two of them walk to the sid entrance of the building.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: This is the last semester you get to take dumb classes.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I don’t take dumb classes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: “History of Food”?  120 121 122 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 187.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: (laughing) I don’t take “History of Food.” And you gave me my Walkman, I like it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Well cherish it ‘cause it’s not gonna be around much longer. They walk into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where everyone’s waiting. We can HEAR the rock concert- stomping and clapping from the audience. “Both Sides Now” continues--—

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. JOANNA walks STEVE and LISA--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where the energy of the audience is louder. The STAGE MANAGER is waiting as is the WOMAN at the PA microphone. STEVE and LISA stand there a moment...

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: On your cue, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Are you nervous? STEVE shakes his head “no.” He takes a moment and then no little to the STAGE MANAGER--"I'm ready, let’s go.”

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: House to half, go. The AUDIENCE begins CLAPPING in anticipation-- STAGE MANAGER (CONT’D) House out, go. The theater goes dark and the CLAPPING gets louder--  STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 188.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: STAGE MANAGER (CONT’D) Go Cue l. On the giant screen the “Think Different” commercial star playing to THUNDEROUS CHEERS from the AUDIENCE. We'll HEA but NEVER SEE IT. We HEAR the audio as “Both Sides Now” continues. The famo audio only serves as background. What we’re watching is everyone--everyone but STEVE--taken by the ad. STEVE’s ta by other things he’s remembering. One of them’s Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Here's to the crazy ones. The misfits. The rebels. The troublemakers. STEVE’s standing in the dark next to LISA listening to th words. We MOVE IN SLOWLY on his face as he prepares to go VOICE OVER (CONT’D) The round pegs in the square holes. The ones who see things differently. And we start to INTERCUT with various people out in the house, which is packed with 2,600 eager people--ANDY HERTZFELD...WOZ taking his seat... VOICE OVER (CONT’D) They're not fond of rules. And they have no respect for the status quo. You can quote them, disagree with them, glorify or vilify them. AVIE TEVANIAN...ANDREA CUNNINGHAM... VOICE OVER (CONT’D) About the only thing you can't do is ignore them. Because they change things. They push the human race forward. JOANNA slips in the back...with SCULLEY... VOICE OVER (CONT’D) And while some may see them as the crazy ones, we see genius. And we're backstage on STEVE and LISA again as “Both Side Now” continues over. Is the song regretful like Lisa said does Steve still have a chance to fix himself?  122 STEVE JOBS - Shooting Script 03/19/15 189.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: VOICE OVER (CONT’D) Because the people who think they're crazy enough to change the world are the ones who do.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (whispering to LISA) You remember that painting you did here on the original Mac? LISA thinks...and then shakes her head “no.”

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispering) I do. And LISA hears this and then wipes a tear from her eye wi her sleeve. The AUDIENCE goes crazy as the PA WOMAN says into the microphone--

dialogues.speaker: PA WOMAN
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, Steve Jobs.
